item.title: Mantoverde makes workers new offer as strike continues
item.description: Mantoverde copper mine in Chile has made a new offer to workers amid ongoing strike action. In 2025, the operation produced 62,308 tons of copper sulfide concentrate and 32,807 tons of copper cathodes, representing approximately 0.4% of global copper production.

item.title: NIC: Record EBITDA margins, strategic asset sale, and strong nickel prices drive positive outlook
item.description: Analysis of nickel market dynamics highlighting record EBITDA margins and strategic asset sales benefiting from strong nickel prices and positive market outlook.

item.title: Nickel Industries December 2025 quarter: Strong HPAL margins, mining rebounds
item.description: Nickel Industries reported US$37.3 million adjusted EBITDA for Q4 2025, with strong HPAL margins despite mining delays from late government approval. Operations rebounded, targeting over 1.4 million wet metric tonnes of ore sales in January. The company anticipates a higher 2026 mining quota of 19 million wmt and progress on the ENC HPAL project.

item.title: Nickel Mines Q4 2025 slides: HPAL strength offsets mining challenges
item.description: Nickel Mines' HPAL operations produced 2,144 tonnes of nickel at 43% above nameplate capacity, with attributable EBITDA up 32% to US$17.2 million. RKEF production rose 1% to 31,561 tonnes despite EBITDA decline. The ENC project advances toward commissioning, supported by a major solar project for low-carbon production.

item.title: Nickel Industries Limited, Q4 2025 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2026
item.description: Nickel Industries held its Q4 2025 earnings call on January 29, 2026, discussing quarterly activities. The webcast covered operational updates and operator instructions. It provides insights into recent production and financial performance.

item.title: Nickel Industries Limited, Q4 2025 Earnings Call
item.description: Nickel Industries Limited held its Q4 2025 earnings call on January 29, 2026, discussing financial performance and operational updates. The transcript covers nickel production advancements and potential sustainability innovations in their operations. This reflects ongoing developments in the nickel sector relevant to technology and market sustainability.

item.title: Aluminum - Price - Chart - Historical Data - News
item.description: Aluminum prices fluctuated on January 29, 2026, falling to $3,230.50 USD/T (down 1.12%) before rising to $3,306.20 USD/T (up 1.20%), with monthly gains of 8-10% and yearly increases over 26%. On January 28, prices hit 3,296 USD/T, a near 4-year high, up 8.78% in four weeks and 24.6% over 12 months.

item.title: Aluminum - Price - Chart - Historical Data - News
item.description: Aluminum prices fluctuated on January 29, 2026, reaching 3,306.20 USD/T amid China's capacity limits at 45 million tons, production disruptions in Iceland, Mozambique, and Australia, and rising demand from the energy transition. Traders worry about global producers' ability to ramp up supply quickly. A weaker US dollar and geopolitical tensions further supported prices, with recent rises hitting over three-year highs due to Chinese supply constraints.

item.title: Steelmaking raw material prices increase through January
item.description: All but one of the tracked steelmaking raw materials, including coking coal, pig iron, shredded scrap, busheling scrap, zinc, and aluminum, increased in price over the last month, with collective prices up 8% month-on-month. Shredded scrap rose to $420 per gross ton and busheling to $423/gt, 8-14% higher than three months ago. Iron ore fines eased to $106/dmt, down 1% month-on-month, while buyers expect further scrap price increases in February due to weather disruptions.

item.title: Stainless Steel Market Watch Intensifies as Inventory Rises and Demand Remains Sluggish
item.description: Social inventory of stainless steel in China rose to 853,000 mt by January 29, 2026, up 1.05% week-over-week. Demand remains sluggish amid rising inventories.

item.title: Steelmaking Raw Material Prices Increase Through January
item.description: Steelmaking raw materials experienced broad-based price increases in January, with coking coal, pig iron, scrap, zinc, and aluminum all rising. Collectively, prices rose 8% month-over-month, with seven of eight tracked products more expensive than three months ago and all higher than year-ago levels.

item.title: The nickel production of Nornickel Russia in 2026 is expected to be similar to the previous year
item.description: Nornickel of Russia expects its nickel production to reach 193,000-203,000 metric tons in 2026, roughly in line with 2025 output of 198,521 tonnes. The company attributes slight reductions to a temporary rise in disseminated ore percentages and is upgrading mining equipment while starting construction at Skalisty Mine to restore rich ore production. CEO Vladimir Potanin described the decline as temporary, with no plans for artificial cuts.

item.title: The growing role of critical minerals in global innovation
item.description: Leaders at the World Economic Forum Annual Meeting 2026 will discuss balancing environmental protection with economic growth in critical minerals mining, including nickel for EVs. Demand for these minerals is projected to rise over 3.4 times by 2040 to achieve net zero by 2050. The article emphasizes responsible mining practices to build trust through environmental stewardship and community benefits.[1]

item.title: Trump Says U.S. Produces More Steel Than Japan for First Time in 26 Years
item.description: President Trump highlighted that the U.S. is now producing more steel than Japan for the first time in 26 years, marking a historic comeback in U.S. manufacturing. He noted that steel companies were closing four years ago but have since recovered, with multiple steel plants currently being built.

item.title: Rio Tinto strengthens its global low-carbon aluminium footprint through joint acquisition with Chalco of Votorantim's interest in CBA
item.description: Rio Tinto and Chalco have jointly acquired Votorantim's interest in CBA to expand low-carbon aluminum production. This move enhances Rio Tinto's global sustainable aluminum capabilities. The acquisition aligns with efforts to reduce carbon emissions in aluminum manufacturing.

item.title: Metal Stocks Plunge on Profit-Taking, Fed Fears
item.description: The Nifty Metal index plummeted nearly 5% on January 30, 2026, reversing recent gains as investors booked profits amid Federal Reserve concerns.

item.title: Copper Price Today, January 30: Why Are Copper Rates Hitting Record Highs
item.description: Copper prices reached record highs above $14,000 per ton on January 30, 2026, driven by speculative buying from Chinese funds, weak US dollar, and demand from renewables and electrification. Physical demand remains low with high exchange stocks, potentially leading to corrections. Supply constraints from slow mine development exacerbate price volatility.

item.title: Copper Shining! Metal's record rally has boosted the fortunes of this ...
item.description: Hindustan Copper plans to expand mine capacity from 4 MT to over 12 MT with ₹2,000 crore investment over five to six years, targeting 20% volume growth in FY2026 at over 40% margins. The expansion supports rising copper demand from EVs, renewables, AI data centers, and grid expansion amid a weak US dollar. Production costs are around $5,500 per tonne.

item.title: Final Cowley assays expand copper system
item.description: Final assays from Cowley expand the copper system, as reported in recent exploration updates. The findings indicate potential growth in copper resources at the site.

item.title: Autonomous Copper Refining at Olympic Dam: Tech Guide - Olympic Dam's Revolutionary Autonomous Copper Refining Technology Breakthrough
item.description: Olympic Dam has introduced a revolutionary autonomous copper refining technology featuring robotic arms for advanced processing. This innovation represents a breakthrough in copper metallurgy and processing technology. The article provides a tech guide on this development published today.

item.title: FNI unit ships first nickel ore cargo for 2026
item.description: Ipilan Nickel Corp., a subsidiary of Global Ferronickel Holdings, Inc., shipped its first nickel ore cargo of 2026, consisting of 53,912 wet metric tons of low-grade nickel ore to China. The company targets production of at least 1.5 million WMT for the year, with a sales mix of 52.6% low-grade and 47.4% medium-grade ore. Mine development includes expanding areas, building haul roads, and installing environmental protections to meet targets while complying with regulations.

item.title: Solway to restart Guatemala nickel plant after price surge
item.description: Swiss-based Solway Investment Group plans to restart its PRONICO nickel plant and CGN mine in Guatemala within months, following a nickel price surge to $19,160 per ton and the lifting of U.S. sanctions. The facility has an annual capacity of 25,000 metric tons of ferronickel, with the mine capable of extracting up to 2.2 million tons of nickel ore. Restart is anticipated around April to May 2026, indicating high prices are enabling resumption of previously curtailed production.

item.title: Global Ferronickel unit sets 2026 output target
item.description: Global Ferronickel announced that its Ipilan unit has commenced 2026 mining operations with the first nickel ore shipment. The company has set specific output targets for the year amid ongoing operations.

item.title: Nickel Industries cements leadership in ENC, welcomes Sphere as strategic partner
item.description: Nickel Industries increased its stake in the ENC project to 46%, becoming the largest shareholder, while Sphere acquired a 10% interest at a US$2.4 billion valuation, reducing cash outflows by US$207 million. The company secured a 15-year MOU for 14 million WMT/year limonite ore supply for the Sampala Project. This strengthens financial flexibility and positions Nickel Industries for battery-grade nickel production as ENC nears commissioning.

item.title: Nickel Industries completes strategic partner’s entry into ENC project, revises acquisition terms
item.description: ASX-listed Nickel Industries completed Sphere's entry into the ENC project and revised acquisition terms. The update enhances project ownership and financial terms for the nickel processor.

item.title: Nickel Industries cements leadership in ENC, welcomes Sphere as strategic partner
item.description: Nickel Industries increases its stake in the ENC project to 46%, becoming the largest shareholder, while welcoming Sphere as a 10% strategic partner at a US$2.4 billion valuation. This deal reduces future cash outflows by US$207 million and secures a 15-year exclusive limonite ore supply MOU for the Sampala Project. The partnership supports transition to battery-grade nickel and cobalt for electric vehicles, enhancing supply chain reliability.

item.title: Large aluminum deposit near Tisdale could enhance industry in Sask
item.description: A massive aluminum deposit, the Thor Project near Tisdale, Saskatchewan, contains over 6.8 billion tonnes of alumina within a small 16x16 mile area, equating to about a third of known world supply. Canadian Energy Metals' Preliminary Economic Assessment confirms an inferred resource of 86.6 billion tonnes. The deposit allows for the greenest method to produce aluminum.

item.title: Green Nickel, Global Future
item.description: Neo Energy is redefining Indonesia's nickel sector through integrated mining, processing, and industrial development on a sustainable platform. The company operates over 12,000 hectares of nickel mines and green-powered industrial parks, including a high-pressure acid leach (HPAL) facility targeted for 2029 completion. These efforts position Indonesia centrally in the global energy transition.

item.title: Sources say that India will unveil incentives for lithium and nickel processing
item.description: India plans to offer incentives, including a 15% capital subvention starting April 1, 2026, for companies setting up nickel and lithium processing plants to boost production and support its energy transition. This addresses the lack of domestic processing capacity, currently dominated by China, amid targets for 30% electric car penetration by 2030. The initiative focuses on critical minerals essential for EV batteries.

item.title: US ALUMINUM: Extruders remain cautious for 2026 after an up-and-down 2025
item.description: US aluminum extruders express caution for 2026 amid high billet costs, import competition, and uncertain trade policies, despite some strong January demand. New orders for extruded products rose 5.1% through November 2025 vs 2024, but shipments fell 1.4%. Expectations include potential tariff reforms on Canadian P1020 to lower premiums and boost demand.

item.title: CME Hikes Copper Margins Amid Record Price Surge
item.description: Global copper prices have reached unprecedented levels, prompting CME Group to raise margins on copper futures by 20% effective January 30, 2026, due to extreme volatility. Prices on the LME exceeded $6 per pound, or over $14,000 per metric tonne. Analysts like Goldman Sachs forecast a decline to $11,000-$11,500 per tonne by year-end 2026 amid potential U.S. tariffs.

item.title: Chalco, Rio Tinto to Buy Brazil's CBA in $886 Million Push for Greener Aluminum
item.description: China's Chalco and Rio Tinto will acquire a 68.6% stake in Brazil's Companhia Brasileira de Alumínio (CBA) for $886 million to secure low-carbon aluminum supply amid surging prices. CBA, powered by renewable energy, produced 364,500 tons in 2024, over one-third of Brazil's output. The deal supports greener production as aluminum futures hit record highs near $3,356 per ton.

item.title: Is aluminium scrap quietly rewriting the global metals playbook especially with EU scrap tension from solar PV India's new policies
item.description: The article examines how global aluminium scrap flows, prices, and policies are shifting, with particular focus on India's new regulations adding secondary aluminium to its list of regulated industries under the Greenhouse Gases Emission Intensity Target Rules, 2025. It highlights NALCO's plans to develop 200-300 MW of renewable power capacity paired with battery storage to reduce coal dependence and support sustainable aluminium smelting, while also addressing the challenge of recycling aluminium from solar installations, which now account for 8 million tonnes globally.

item.title: Aluminum Beverage Can Market Outlook 2026-2034
item.description: The market analysis projects the aluminum beverage can market will grow from $41.9 billion in 2025 to $57.4 billion by 2034, driven by sustainability demand and aluminum's 100% recyclability. The report highlights innovations in printed electronics and temperature-sensitive inks creating premium packaging opportunities, with the smart aluminum beverage can market projected to reach $1.2 billion by 2026.

item.title: Steel prices today, January 31st: Declining on international markets

item.title: IIT-M develops green method to recover metals from e-waste using natural solvents
item.description: Researchers at IIT Madras developed a sustainable method to recover valuable metals from electronic waste using environment-friendly solvents derived from natural compounds like thymol and capric acid. Unlike conventional acid-based extraction techniques, this green solvent approach is non-toxic, water-efficient, and generates no hazardous waste, with potential applications for scaling up industrial recycling processes.

item.title: Nickel Industries showcases sustainability in quarterly update

The article also discusses nickel's role in green hydrogen, electric vehicles, and cellulosic ethanol production as part of the energy transition.

item.title: Advancing Nickel MMC Coatings: Electroplating Models, Tooling Innovations for Hard Chromium Alternatives
item.description: The EU-funded MOZART project develops nickel dispersion coatings enriched with nanoparticles as a sustainable alternative to hard chromium plating, achieving hardness up to 1,000 HV. It integrates electrochemical characterization and CAE technology to predict nanoparticle content in deposits and designs custom plating tooling. This innovation supports eco-friendly electroplating for various components.

item.title: The first Energy Release contract in the Aosta Valley is underway: agreement signed between the CVA Group and Cogne Acciai Speciali
item.description: CVA will construct four new photovoltaic plants in Sicily with over 20 MW capacity, expected to produce 593,600 MWh fully operational by 2026. This marks the first Energy Release agreement in the Aosta Valley and supports Cogne Acciai Speciali's green energy transition and reduced environmental impact of production.

item.title: Cogne Acciai Speciali mulls expansion in U.S.
item.description: After four acquisitions over the past two years, Italian stainless steel and nickel alloy producer Cogne Acciai Speciali is considering further growth in the U.S. market. The company secured EUR 245 million through two capital increases to fund previous acquisitions and is preparing for its next expansion move.

item.title: Aluminum Falls from Over 3-Year High
item.description: Aluminum futures in the UK fell to $3,100 per tonne, retreating sharply from the over three-year high of $3,270 on January 28th as traders reconsidered speculative positions. Trading volumes for base metals in China remained at unprecedented highs, indicating position closures after metals tested peaks. Aluminum fell to 3,054.20 USD/T on February 2, down 2.04% from the previous day.

item.title: Uzbekistan Launches Its First Aluminum Can Plant with IFC Support to Drive Sustainable Production
item.description: Uzbekistan has launched its first greenfield aluminum can production plant in Tashkent with IFC's $18 million investment, aiming to supply recyclable metal packaging to beverage producers and reduce import reliance. The facility will produce up to 1.1 billion cans annually using energy-efficient equipment, create over 200 jobs, and align with climate goals through sustainable practices. IFC will also support environmental standards and green building certification.

item.title: Green Steel Production: Hydrogen Tech & Future Trends
item.description: This article examines hydrogen-driven green steel production technologies that are revolutionizing manufacturing in 2026, focusing on how hydrogen technology is transforming the steel industry toward more sustainable practices.

item.title: Copper Extends Losses in Broad Metal Selloff
item.description: Copper fell more than 5% to around $5.5 per pound on Monday, reaching one-month lows and extending losses from the prior session. The metal is down about 15% from last week’s all-time high amid a continued broader metals selloff.

item.title: Copper is down by 2.01%
item.description: Copper decreased 2.01% to 5.8051 USD/Lbs as part of recent market movements. This reflects short-term downward pressure in commodity trading.

item.title: The hidden powers of porous copper
item.description: Researchers at Arizona State University have developed a 3D-printing method using micro continuous liquid interface production (µCLIP) to create intricate copper components with nanoscale pores. This innovation allows engineering copper to intentionally oxidize for applications in information security, such as self-destructing chips exposed to air. The technology also supports sustainable manufacturing and medical implants that safely disintegrate.

item.title: Nickel Hits 4-week Low
item.description: Nickel decreased to 16,867 USD/T, marking the lowest price since January 2026. Over the past 4 weeks, nickel lost 2.38%, though it has increased 11.62% over the last 12 months. On February 2, 2026, nickel fell to 17,010 USD/T, down 3.10% from the previous day.

item.title: Nickel Declines from Recent Peak
item.description: Nickel futures in the UK sank to $17,700 per tonne after hovering near the 19-month high of $19,000 throughout January. The decline tracks drops in other base metals due to a rebounding dollar triggering the close of speculative positions. Contracts remain sharply higher since the start of the year.

item.title: Steel Prices Rising Again? February 2026 Metal Market Update
item.description: This market update discusses rising steel mill prices and extended lead times in the metal roofing industry, alongside tight aluminum supply reaching four-year price highs. The analysis covers how energy costs and winter weather are impacting production, why inventory levels remain lean across the supply chain, and recommendations for contractors managing Q1 and Q2 projects.

item.title: Nickel Prices Plunge as Macro Fund Outflows and High Inventories Weigh on Market
item.description: On February 2, 2026, nickel prices experienced limit-down declines due to macro fund outflows and high inventories, with LME stocks over 280,000 mt and domestic visible inventory elevated. China's refined nickel production rose 20% month-on-month in January, increasing supply pressure amid weak downstream demand. Short-term pressure persists, but Indonesian quota reductions could support a rebound.

item.title: US aluminium prices break away as tariffs collide with global supply strain
item.description: US aluminium prices surged past USD 5000/tonne due to tariffs boosting domestic production like Century Aluminum's Mt. Holly restart (50kt idle capacity reactivated, full by June), falling imports, and shrinking stocks. Global strains include South32's Mozal smelter deactivation in Mozambique and Century's Grundartangi output cut by two-thirds in Iceland due to equipment issues.

item.title: Nuton: A better way to produce copper
item.description: Rio Tinto's Nuton technology is enabling the Johnson Camp mine to become the lowest-carbon primary copper producer, setting a new benchmark for sustainability in copper mining. The technology drives lower emissions and improved environmental performance. It represents a significant advancement in sustainable copper production methods.

item.title: FHE materials bend the rules
item.description: Screen-printed copper-based circuits for flexible hybrid electronics (FHE) offer cost-efficiency, mechanical flexibility, and environmental benefits. These innovations expand possibilities in electronics manufacturing. The technology emphasizes sustainability through reduced material use and adaptability.

item.title: [SMM Nickel Sulphate Daily Review] February 3: Weak Sentiment in Both Purchasing and Sales, Nickel Salt Prices Decline
item.description: On February 3, the SMM battery-grade nickel sulphate index price stood at 31,939 yuan/mt. Weak sentiment affected both purchasing and sales, leading to declining prices for nickel salt. This reflects ongoing market pressures in the nickel sulphate segment.

item.title: Aluminum and copper prices take breather after explosive start to 2026
item.description: Aluminum prices steadied at $3,197.50 a ton on the LME, the highest in over three years, following a strong start to 2026 amid bullish industrial metals run. Concerns include potential softening Chinese demand and geopolitical risks from US tariffs on countries trading with Iran.

item.title: Prysmian signs €2.3 billion contract for UK power link project
item.description: Italian cable maker Prysmian has signed a contract worth over €2.3 billion with SP Energy Networks and National Grid to build a power link between Scotland and England. The project, called Eastern Green Link 4, will connect the electrical grids of Scotland and England as part of a significant infrastructure project for the Italian firm.

item.title: US ALUMINUM: Historically wide spreads in prime scrap market change 2026 contract behavior
item.description: Wide spreads in US aluminum scrap markets, driven by record Midwest premiums, tariff uncertainty, and supply-demand shifts, are disrupting 2026 contracts. UBC scrap prices averaged 111.25 cents/lb in January, at 46% of MWT costs, down from prior norms. Buyers and sellers hesitate on long-term deals amid policy volatility and scrap gluts.

item.title: Acciaierie d'Italia to start preferential negotiations with Azerbaijani consortium on acquisition of former Ilva plants
item.description: Extraordinary commissioners of Acciaierie d’Italia and ILVA in extraordinary administration have requested authorization from Italy’s Ministry of Enterprises and Made in Italy to begin preferential negotiations with an Azerbaijani consortium (Baku Steel Company CJSC and Azerbaijan Investment Company OJSC) for the sale of the former Ilva steel plants.[8] Ten proposals had been received by the January 10 deadline, and the chosen consortium was selected based on criteria including financial stability, industrial sustainability, and expected benefits for employment and local communities.[8]
